abstracts.cdata!:
The Ethiopia Electricity Access Rural
            Expansion Project, Phase II and Global Partnership on
            Output-Based Aid Grant had a moderately unsatisfactory
            performance from the Bank and an unsatisfactory performance
            from the borrower. The lessons learned from this project
            were as followed: Outsourcing connections requires the
            establishment/enforcement of effective quality control
            mechanisms; A proper assessment of utility's practice
            and technical and safety standards of connections is needed
            to avoid a high rate of connection rectification after
            verification; Risk of a negative impact of supporting a
            major connection program on the electricity supply-demand
            balance should be carefully assessed; In a low capacity
            environment, even when relying on an existing institution,
            it is important to assess the institutions ability to
            coordinate internally to assure successful implementation of
            the proposed activity; Since poor rural hhs targeted by
            GPOBA grants do not provide a significant revenue stream to
            the service provider, analyzing the government pro-poor
            access policy and crafting incentives for utilities to reach
            low income hhs is crucial in project design; All major
            barriers to access should be addressed by OBA financing; and
            OBA innovative projects may require flexibility in order to
            make adjustments to the design during implementation to
            achieve the PDO in a changing sector or country specific environment.
